184997020.review:
Dungeon Defenders II is a vibrant mix of tower defense and action RPG that’s perfect for solo or co-op play. The colorful art style and creative hero designs make it fun to explore and strategize. Each hero brings unique abilities, so experimenting with different combinations keeps the gameplay fresh. The mix of building defenses and diving into the action yourself is both engaging and rewarding.

However, the game has its downsides. The progression system can feel grindy, especially if you’re chasing specific upgrades. Microtransactions for cosmetics and other content are noticeable, which might be a turn-off for some players.

Despite these issues, Dungeon Defenders II is a great pick for those who enjoy strategic combat with a dash of teamwork. It’s easy to lose track of time as you fend off waves of enemies and perfect your defenses. If you’re into tower defense games with a bit more action, this one’s worth a shot.

184911204.review:
"A fun and addictive tower defense RPG with a lot of heart!"

Dungeon Defenders II is a fantastic blend of tower defense strategy and RPG elements. Whether you’re playing solo or with friends, it offers hours of fun and challenging gameplay. The colorful, cartoonish art style makes it visually appealing, and the variety of heroes and towers allows you to approach each level in multiple ways.

The core mechanics are simple but rewarding—build defenses, defeat waves of enemies, and protect your crystal. However, the game adds layers of complexity with character progression, loot collection, and the ability to level up and upgrade your heroes and towers. It’s this RPG-like progression that keeps you coming back for more.

One of the standout features of Dungeon Defenders II is its cooperative multiplayer mode. The ability to team up with friends or random players to tackle tougher challenges makes it feel like a truly collaborative experience. The teamwork required to defend against the waves of enemies is a lot of fun and fosters a sense of camaraderie.

That being said, the game’s grind can get a little repetitive at times, especially when you’re trying to farm for the best loot or level up your heroes. The free-to-play model also means there are microtransactions, though they don't feel as intrusive as in some other games.

Overall, Dungeon Defenders II is a blast to play, especially with friends. It combines the best elements of tower defense and RPGs into a highly enjoyable experience. If you’re looking for a game with strategy, teamwork, and a lot of loot, this one’s definitely worth checking out!

184436457.review:
Dungeon Defenders II is an iconic title and one of a very few games that actually offer a third person perspective experience in a tower defense game. The game has been out for almost a decade now and still receives updates to this day yet its not enough.

Let me start with the fact that the game is very difficult to start at. It is very anti-beginner friendly. My first approach to the game ended in a single session because I got overwhelmed. Not gonna lie, the game gave me a weak first impression. It didn’t make me want to play or discover more. Only because I gave the game a second chance and put a few hours with a leap of faith, I was able to discover what it is about and it is about grinding the hell out of it. The beginning of the game is simply boring. Not much effort went into it and it shows. The campaign gives you an idea of the basics but it doesn’t teach you anything else. There are a ton of things that are available to you but they lack explanation or introductions. There is a ton you have to figure out on your own. That’s why I think that the campaign could as well go to the trash can. We need something else, we need something better.

Unfortunately, the game is completely broken. There is a glitch that when you load into a match, you can load with exactly 1 gear score. I believe it changed my gear score mid-game at least once too. It doesn’t matter what gear you currently have equipped, the glitch will cause it to be at a minimum level making you unable to play. As far as my research goes, there is no solution to this problem so when that happens, your only option is to leave the match and try again in either the same lobby or some other hoping it won’t glitch out again. Imagine my irritation when I was trying to set up a game earlier today and it glitched out like that probably close to 30 times in a row… I am not kidding nor am I exaggerating. I found mentions of the glitch dating back to 2019. Despite the game being constantly updated, it is full of problems that nobody bothers to take care of and it leaves us very little hope that those will ever be fixed. 

Another problem I would like to mention is closely related to monsters and bosses. They have a tendency to glitch out at the entrances of their spawning zones making them stuck. After I got a better understanding of the game, I wanted to accomplish a total semi-afk experience where I would only be checking on the game to start another round. This is what the already mentioned grind looks like for the most part. It was supposed to help me with setup for the last achievement as well as with farming in-game resources. I couldn’t even do that because the mobs kept getting stuck outside of my tower’s reach. In order to make them unstuck you have to go to the edge of their spawning zones and aggro them onto you so that they start chasing you and get unstuck. This is very annoying and wastes a lot of time. I can’t even trust the game to leave it unattended for a moment without something going wrong…

In summary, I had a lot of positive moments with the game as well as with the people I randomly met while playing the game. There were moments that will stay with me as nice memories. Unfortunately, the positives quickly got overwhelmed by the amount of negatives I was facing every session. The deeper I got into the end game, the more issues I was experiencing. In the current state, the game is unplayable and I cannot recommend it. Judging by how long these issues had already been present, I worry that they will never be resolved…

184260974.review:
I used to enjoy playing Dungeon Defenders 2, but my experience with the community and developer team has completely ruined the game for me. Here's why:

Toxic Developer Team: The developers are incredibly unprofessional and hostile. Constructive criticism or differing opinions are often met with bans without explanation.

Unjust Bans: Many players, have seen accounts banned for no clear reason. There's no transparency or fair appeal process, making the game feel unsafe to invest time in.

Hostile Discord Environment: The official Discord server is a mess. If you disagree with the developers or moderators, you're immediately targeted and insulted by both staff and community members.

Player Identity Abuse: There are people actively impersonating skilled players, using their names to scam others or spread fake screenshots to damage reputations. The developers have done little to address this issue, which only worsens the toxic environment.

Unresponsive Developers: Trying to contact the developers is pointless. Messages go unanswered, and there's no indication that any complaints or reports ever reach a manager or are properly addressed.

Unless drastic changes are made to the management and moderation of the community, I can't recommend this game to anyone. It’s a shame, as the core gameplay had potential.

184012492.review:
Dungeon Defenders 2 gets co-op wrong, it's no longer a party game, but a single player game where 1 guy can play all roles.

While the mechanic of being able to choose 4 heroes to actively swap between in a mission might seem intriguing, it massively dampens the need for other friends to compensate for what your one hero might not do so well, in contrast to how Dungeon Defenders 1 works, where you only get to play as 1 hero at a time, therefore needing friends to help you out.

I did not really like the progression either, but it has been a while since i played so i don't remember the details anymore.

183629072.review:
This game is undoubtedly pay to win and has several annoying issues, mainly because these are very confusing as a new player:
- making a consistent lobby with friends (you can't just join off steam you have to make a party in the esc menu to keep playing)
- there is a public town and a private tavern that have the same things (making parties was more confusing due to this)
- creating game matches and not realizing they are public (you can make private games but it was kind of hidden and wasn't intuitive to find out how to do it)
- friends timing out when trying to join your private matches
- figuring out what to do after you beat the campaign (there are many tabs of maps to do and some of them will completely destroy you)
- figuring out what maps you've already done before, and how strong you have to be to do them (there is hardly any information about the maps when you click on them)
- the map names and zones are confusing. For example, my friend had 1 adventure map left to do and we had to look up how to see what the last map was in an obscure menu. That map that was listed was nowhere in the adventure tab so we had to guess.
- a kind of overwhelming about of shops in the lobby that aren't really explained at all and seem irrelevant for the beginning of the game (was this because I bought the game when it came out ages ago? not sure)

On top of the confusing issues, you can swipe your credit card on just about anything (buying gold, unlocking characters, powering up your gear/weapons, battle pass, bag tabs, etc etc) and playing solo seems a lot harder than playing with a group (at least at the beginning of the game). There have also been a lot of UI bugs (tutorial text staying on the screen forever) and wonky/bugged out numbers on gear that seem to fix themselves if you restart.

Even with all of these problems that have driven me absolutely insane over the last week lol, this game is still a free co-op tower defense game that looks pretty good and has fun levels and characters. You get to play 4 characters at a time and swap between them during the matches which is enjoyable for strategy setup. Once you get to the very easy/low level cap all of your characters level at once which is a relief. It still gets updated and seems to have an active community. The pay to win is there if you want to skip grinding I suppose, but if you want to defend some dungeons with your pals and have something to grind at this is definitely that game. I don't know why I wrote this whole thing but you can go play it now and see if you enjoy it hehe :))))

183594368.review: it is very grindy but worth the suffering to enjoy the endgame and help newbies

183522882.review:
FOMO Microtransactions, Lootcrates, Battle Pass that takes WAY TOO LONG to level up. Over 200 hours, I'm at level 28 out of 80. 18 Achievements, 17 of which you unlock in the first few hours, the last one will take thousands of hours. The end-game mode is the same level progressively harder each time with a different level here and there. Unfortunately I really dislike that specific map and can't see me WANTING to play it 5,000+ times in the future.
The game is good, but the terrible business practices including FOMO and paying for inventory when there's countless things you need to keep, along with the life consuming grind; This game isn't worth the commitment.
